Award.AwardTitle: Biochemical and Biophysical Characterization of the Lambda Capsid

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
The assembly of an infectious virus within the cell is a remarkably conserved process in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic viruses. For instance, the assembly of most large DNA viruses includes a "packaging" step, where the viral genome is physically inserted into the confines of a pre-assembled capsid shell. Genome packaging is catalyzed by a terminase enzyme, which utilizes the energy of ATP hydrolysis to fuel the reaction. This ultimately yields a capsid that contains tightly packaged DNA, which can generate over 20 atmospheres of internal pressure. The packaging process triggers a major reorganization of the proteins assembled into the capsid shell, which often results in expansion of the structure. This is a remarkable process whereby the spherical procapsid shell thins, acquires a mature angular shape, and roughly doubles the internal volume to accept the entire genome length. Exactly when procapsid expansion occurs, what drives it, and what role it plays is not fully understood in any system. In most cases, a "decoration" protein adds to the surface of the expanded shell to stabilize the structure against the tremendous internal forces generated by the packaged DNA. The physical and chemical features that mediate decoration protein binding to the expanded shell and how these interactions stabilize the structure remain poorly characterized. Once the entire genome has been packaged, the terminase motor is ejected from the nucleocapsid and is replaced by "finishing proteins" to yield the virus particle. How this "hand-off" takes place without release of the tightly packaged, highly pressurized DNA is poorly understood in all virus systems. Bacteriophage lambda has been intensely studied using genetic, biochemical, biophysical, and structural approaches and defined biochemical assays are available to interrogate each step along the assembly pathway. This project capitalizes on these defined systems to interrogate three critical steps in viral genome packaging that are common and essential for the assembly of all large double-stranded DNA viruses. Specifically, this project will define and characterize the physical and chemical forces that (i) drive procapsid expansion, (ii) mediate decoration protein assembly of the expanded capsid shell, and (iii) facilitate handoff of the nucleocapsid from the motor to the finishing proteins without release of the tightly packaged, highly pressurized DNA. The project incorporates collaborative studies to provide a complementary structural framework with which to understand the biochemical data. Procapsid expansion, stabilization of the DNA-filled capsid by decoration proteins, and hand-off of the pressurized nucleocapsid to finishing proteins is observed from phages to the herpesviruses. This research will reveal fundamental new information on virus assembly mechanisms. Understanding the physical and chemical mechanisms by which a capsid can expand without fracturing will serve as a paradigm for a large class of macromolecular transformations observed throughout biology. This research will provide a detailed understanding of essential steps in virus assembly and will be applicable to a variety of biological processes.

Broader Impact
This work will further afford technical advances that will allow adaptation of the lambda system as a nanotechnology platform for a variety of bioengineering applications. Importantly, the project will provide training opportunities for students spanning from undergraduate summer research programs, to graduate Ph.D. thesis studies and to post-graduate research experiences. This research project will result in the training and mentoring of promising young scientists. The recruitment and training of minority scientists is an important component of this research program. Undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral students will perform the studies described in this application which will provide training for a new generation of scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All viruses are composed of a genome (DNA or RNA) covered by a protective protein coat (the capsid). Capsid shell assembly and maturation are essential steps in the development of all viruses. In the case of the complex double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) viruses, which include many that infect bacteria (bacteriophages) and humans (herpes and adenoviruses), the capsid is independently assembled, and DNA is then packaged into the pre-assembled shell. Genome packaging drives a shell maturation process, and in many cases the subsequent addition of a “decoration” protein to the capsid. In these cases, shell decoration is required to stabilize the infectious particle in the environment. The overall goal of this project was to characterize capsid assembly and maturation in bacteriophage lambda, which serves as a model system for all the dsDNA viruses, both prokaryotic and eukaryotic.

 

Our studies characterized the physical, chemical and structural features of the shell maturation reaction. These studies revealed fundamental interactions that may be shared by all of the dsDNA viruses. Since shell maturation is common to all of the dsDNA viruses, the results may have broad implications for all of them. We further examined the shell decoration reaction, which involves addition of the “gpD” decoration protein to the mature shell surface. We identified specific molecular interactions between the capsid proteins and the gpD decoration protein and defined their roles in capsid stability. For instance, we found that a specific single mutation in the capsid protein completely inhibits shell assembly. The phenotype of the mutant protein allows for the first time characterization of protein contacts essential for shell assembly and thus virus infectivity. In sum, our studies provide fundamental information towards our understanding of how a virus “puts itself together”. This information important for a basic understanding of virus assembly, which is essential to a rapid response to uncharacterized biological agents that may be introduced into the human population either by evolution or as agents of bioterrorism.

 

In the course of our studies on shell maturation and decoration, we realized that the system could be coopted as a nanoparticle platform for therapeutic and diagnostic (theranostic) applications. Specifically, virus like particles (VLPs) can be assembled in vitro and the shells can be decorated with purified gpD protein. We have constructed a number of modified gpD proteins that allow site-specific modification of the decoration protein and thus modular decoration of VLPs. Modifications include proteins, small molecules, carbohydrates and synthetic display ligands. We have demonstrated that the chimeric proteins can be used to simultaneously decorate the lambda capsid shell in a tunable surface density to afford particles that are physically homogeneous and that can be manufactured to display a variety of ligands in a defined composition. These studies pave the way for construction of “designer nanoparticles” in a user-defined manner to deliver drugs to specific cell types (e.g., cancer cells), to “paint” specific cells and tissues with colored particles for detection (e.g., a diagnostic reagent), for nano-bioreactor and vaccine applications to name a few possibilities. A patent has been awarded for this work (US 9,765,122 B2).

 

As a proof of concept, we constructed a Herceptin-gpD fusion protein (gpD-Her). Herceptin is a monoclonal antibody that interferes with the HER2 receptor associated with some breast cancers. We assembled lambda VLPs decorated with gpD-Her (for specific cell targeting), gpD-fluorescein (for detection), and polyethylene glycol (PEG, for immune evasion) in defined ratios. The particles possess a wild-type icosahedral shell morphology, except that the gpD-Her decorated particles exhibit a “furry” shell surface. We next demonstrated that the Her-decorated particles are taken up by Her2-expressing cancer cells, but not “normal” cells. In other words, specific targeting of cancer cells has been accomplished. Given that the particles can be engineered to carry “drug cargos”, this sets the stage for delivery of cancer drugs specifically to cancer cells.

 

Broader Impacts. The studies described above have resulted in 11 peer reviewed publications and have provided mechanistic insight into the general features of virus capsid assembly. Thus, this work has significantly contributed to the greater scientific community. In addition, the work has served to train five undergraduate summer students (all currently in graduate school, medical school or employed in biotech), five graduate students (one currently in the lab; one currently a post-doc fellow, two are professors in community college) and five post-doctoral fellows (one currently in the lab and four employed in biotech). Six of the trainees are minority scientists, all of which are currently in graduate school or employed in biotech. A major interest of the PI centers on diversification of the scientific workforce and the success of my trainees has been gratifying.
